articles.headline: Trump’s Future: Tons of Cash and Plenty of Options for Spending It
articles.snippet: When President Trump departs the White House, he will have a huge pile of cash to fuel his future ambitions. He can hold rallies, hire staff and even lay groundwork for a potential 2024 run.
articles.abstract: When President Trump departs the White House, he will have a huge pile of cash to fuel his future ambitions. He can hold rallies, hire staff and even lay groundwork for a potential 2024 run.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump will exit the White House as a private citizen next month perched atop a pile of campaign cash unheard-of for an outgoing president, and with few legal limits on how he can spend it.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Tesla, Profitable at Last, Bulls Its Way Into the S&P 500
articles.snippet: The electric-car maker will be the biggest addition in the history of the benchmark index. Will that settle down its swings?
articles.abstract: The electric-car maker will be the biggest addition in the history of the benchmark index. Will that settle down its swings?
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market has never seen anything quite like Tesla.

articles.headline: Trump Claims Credit for Vaccines. Some of His Backers Don’t Want to Take Them.
articles.snippet: A deep distrust of the government is fueling vaccine hesitancy among Republicans, who are more likely than Democrats to resist being inoculated against Covid-19.
articles.abstract: A deep distrust of the government is fueling vaccine hesitancy among Republicans, who are more likely than Democrats to resist being inoculated against Covid-19.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Elizabeth Graves, an ardent supporter of President Trump, is not opposed to vaccines. She said she had taken flu shots and pneumonia shots and, having just turned 50, was interested in being vaccinated against shingles.

articles.headline: Trump Contradicts Pompeo Over Russia’s Role in Hack
articles.snippet: Hours after the secretary of state said that Moscow was behind the vast cybersecurity breach, the president suggested it might have been China and downplayed the severity of the attack.
articles.abstract: Hours after the secretary of state said that Moscow was behind the vast cybersecurity breach, the president suggested it might have been China and downplayed the severity of the attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hours after Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told a conservative radio show host that “we can say pretty clearly that it was the Russians” behind the vast hack of the federal government and American industry, he was contradicted on Saturday by President Trump, who sought to muddy the intelligence findings by raising the possibility that China was responsible.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: No ‘Negative’ News: How China Censored the Coronavirus
articles.snippet: Thousands of internal directives and reports reveal how Chinese officials stage-managed what appeared online in the early days of the outbreak.
articles.abstract: Thousands of internal directives and reports reveal how Chinese officials stage-managed what appeared online in the early days of the outbreak.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Feb. 7, China’s powerful internet censors experienced an unfamiliar and deeply unsettling sensation. They felt they were losing control.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong, Paul Mozur, Jeff Kao and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: An Oral History of the World’s Biggest Coupon
articles.snippet: Bed Bath & Beyond’s plus-size mailer, known as Big Blue, has made it to TV, eBay, even a mobster’s kitchen drawer. “The poor mailmen,” the company’s former marketing V.P. said, “what we did to them.”
articles.abstract: Bed Bath & Beyond’s plus-size mailer, known as Big Blue, has made it to TV, eBay, even a mobster’s kitchen drawer. “The poor mailmen,” the company’s former marketing V.P. said, “what we did to them.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. found one in the junk drawer at the Santa Monica hide-out of the notorious mobster Whitey Bulger, which goes to show that gangsters are just like everybody else.

articles.headline: In Last Rush, Trump Grants Mining and Energy Firms Access to Public Lands
articles.snippet: The outgoing administration is pushing through approval of corporate projects over the opposition of environmental groups and tribal communities.
articles.abstract: The outgoing administration is pushing through approval of corporate projects over the opposition of environmental groups and tribal communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is rushing to approve a final wave of large-scale mining and energy projects on federal lands, encouraged by investors who want to try to ensure the projects move ahead even after President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. takes office.

articles.headline: Biden Cabinet Leans Centrist, Leaving Some Liberals Frustrated
articles.snippet: Still a work in progress, the president-elect’s personnel choices are more pragmatic and familiar than ideological. It’s what he campaigned on, but the left had hoped for more.
articles.abstract: Still a work in progress, the president-elect’s personnel choices are more pragmatic and familiar than ideological. It’s what he campaigned on, but the left had hoped for more.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His economic and environment teams are a little left of center. His foreign policy picks fall squarely in the Democratic Party’s mainstream. His top White House aides are Washington veterans.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: A President Who Can’t Put Aside Grudges, Even for Good News
articles.snippet: The past week served as a preview of Mr. Trump’s post-presidency: no leadership on debates within his party, but keen attention to waging personal vendettas and cultivating his supporters.
articles.abstract: The past week served as a preview of Mr. Trump’s post-presidency: no leadership on debates within his party, but keen attention to waging personal vendettas and cultivating his supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was among the most consequential weeks of President Trump’s tenure: Across the country, health care workers began receiving a lifesaving coronavirus vaccine. On Capitol Hill, lawmakers closed in on a deal for economic relief aimed at averting a deeper recession. And on Friday, federal regulators authorized a second vaccine.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Giving Billions Fast, MacKenzie Scott Upends Philanthropy
articles.snippet: Through a streamlined operation, Ms. Scott has given away $6 billion this year, much of it to small charities and nonprofits.
articles.abstract: Through a streamlined operation, Ms. Scott has given away $6 billion this year, much of it to small charities and nonprofits.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Monday evening in November, Dorri McWhorter, the chief executive of the Y.W.C.A. Metropolitan Chicago, got a phone call from a representative of the billionaire philanthropist MacKenzie Scott. The news was almost too good to be true: Her group would be receiving a $9 million gift.

articles.headline: The Antitrust Case Against Big Tech, Shaped by Tech Industry Exiles
articles.snippet: Regulators are relying on insiders like Dina Srinivasan, who left her digital ad job after concluding that “Facebook and Google were going to win and everybody else is going to lose.”
articles.abstract: Regulators are relying on insiders like Dina Srinivasan, who left her digital ad job after concluding that “Facebook and Google were going to win and everybody else is going to lose.”
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Three years ago, before she became an antitrust scholar whose work laid the blueprint for a new wave of monopoly lawsuits against Big Tech, Dina Srinivasan was a digital advertising executive bored with her job and worried about the bleak outlook for the industry.

articles.headline: Congress Strikes Long-Sought Stimulus Deal to Provide $900 Billion in Aid
articles.snippet: Democrats and Republicans said they had an agreement on another round of pandemic aid, including direct payments to Americans, jobless benefits and funds for businesses and vaccine distribution.
articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans said they had an agreement on another round of pandemic aid, including direct payments to Americans, jobless benefits and funds for businesses and vaccine distribution.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders on Sunday reached a hard-fought agreement on a $900 billion stimulus package that would send immediate aid to Americans and businesses to help them cope with the economic devastation of the pandemic and fund the distribution of vaccines.

articles.headline: Stimulus Deal Provides Economic Relief, for Now
articles.snippet: The aid package will keep millions from losing jobless benefits. But it comes too late to prevent lasting damage to many families and businesses.
articles.abstract: The aid package will keep millions from losing jobless benefits. But it comes too late to prevent lasting damage to many families and businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: The congressional agreement on a $900 billion dose of aid to fuel the slowing economic recovery has probably spared millions of Americans from a winter of poverty and kept the country from falling back into recession.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: The ‘Red Slime’ Lawsuit That Could Sink Right-Wing Media
articles.snippet: Voting machine companies threaten “highly dangerous” cases against Fox, Newsmax and OAN, says Floyd Abrams.
articles.abstract: Voting machine companies threaten “highly dangerous” cases against Fox, Newsmax and OAN, says Floyd Abrams.
articles.lead_paragraph: Antonio Mugica was in Boca Raton when an American presidential election really melted down in 2000, and he watched with shocked fascination as local government officials argued over hanging chads and butterfly ballots.

articles.headline: The Stimulus Package: What’s in It for You
articles.snippet: Lawmakers agreed to issue stimulus payments of $600 and distribute a federal unemployment benefit of $300 for 11 weeks. But that money will take time to start arriving.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers agreed to issue stimulus payments of $600 and distribute a federal unemployment benefit of $300 for 11 weeks. But that money will take time to start arriving.
articles.lead_paragraph: Another dose of relief is finally on the way for the millions of Americans facing financial distress because of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: She Called Police Over a Neo-Nazi Threat. But the Neo-Nazis Were Inside the Police.
articles.snippet: Death threats linked to police computers and the discovery of far-right chat groups in police departments across Germany have fed concerns about far-right infiltration.
articles.abstract: Death threats linked to police computers and the discovery of far-right chat groups in police departments across Germany have fed concerns about far-right infiltration.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Traveling for work and far from home, Seda Basay-Yildiz received a chilling fax at her hotel: “You filthy Turkish sow,” it read. “We will slaughter your daughter.”

articles.headline: Biden’s Choice of Vilsack for U.S.D.A. Raises Fears for Small Farmers
articles.snippet: Democrats have struggled to win voters in rural America, and critics say the return of Tom Vilsack, a former agriculture secretary, won’t help.
articles.abstract: Democrats have struggled to win voters in rural America, and critics say the return of Tom Vilsack, a former agriculture secretary, won’t help.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Soon after President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. beat President Trump last month, Tom Vilsack, the former agriculture secretary and one of Mr. Biden’s early backers, received an exasperated call from a former aide. Despite the elation over Mr. Biden’s victory, Democrats were again defeated resoundingly in rural America.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Who Takes the Eurostar? Almost No One, as the Pandemic Fuels a Rail Crisis
articles.snippet: A plunge in ridership at the international high-speed train mirrors wider troubles gripping Europe’s railway industry.
articles.abstract: A plunge in ridership at the international high-speed train mirrors wider troubles gripping Europe’s railway industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Earlier this month, David-Alexander Leduc rolled his suitcase down a nearly empty platform at the Gare du Nord train station and scanned his ticket at the turnstile to board the sole Eurostar leaving that day for London.
